channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Baptist Missionary Sentenced to Life in Hard Labor by North Korea
item.description: The South Korean Baptist missionary was accused of trying to build underground churches in North Korea.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: World Briefing: Bombing Thwarted, Israeli Military Says
item.description: Israeli troops on Friday detained a Palestinian man who was wearing a belt packed with explosives at a West Bank intersection that has been the site of previous attacks, Israeli military officials said.
item.dc:creator: By IRIT PAZNER GARSHOWITZ

item.title: Iran Hackers Dangle a Familiar Name to Fish for Data
item.description: Hackers seeking information about Washington’s elite posed as John R. Bolton, a former American ambassador to the United Nations, to friend online users through social media.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER
item.media:description: John R. Bolton, a former ambassador turned cybertarget.

item.title: Norway Moves In to Guard Oil Rig From Greenpeace
item.description: Oil drillers are moving farther north as the Arctic ice retreats, opening areas that were previously inaccessible and as fields to the south are depleted.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: U.S. Sway in Asia Is Imperiled as China Challenges Alliances
item.description: As Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel visited Singapore, the Obama administration’s Asia policy appeared to be turning into a street fight, with the United States playing referee.
item.dc:creator: By HELENE COOPER and JANE PERLEZ
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel in Singapore on Friday.

item.title: In Spanish Riots, Anguish of Those Recovery Forgot
item.description: Four nights of demonstrations in Spain’s tourism capital have highlighted the country’s persistent social tensions and belied signs of relief from years of austerity.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:description: A riot police officer stopped a demonstrator in Barcelona who protested the eviction of squatters from Can Vies, a warehouse.

item.title: Suicide Bomber Is Identified as a Florida Man
item.description: An American who blew himself up in a suicide attack in Syria was identified by officials as Moner Mohammad Abusalha, who has lived in Fort Pierce and Vero Beach.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MARK MAZZETTI, ERIC SCHMITT and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: A photo circulated by jihadists was said to show Moner Mohammad Abusalha, the bomber.

item.title: World Briefing: Terrorism Suspects Arrested in Spain
item.description: The Interior Ministry said Friday that the police had arrested six members of a group who were accused of recruiting militants to fight in Libya and Mali.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: One Man, Two Wives and Many Accepted Forms of Violence in Pakistan
item.description: An uncle and two cousins were among those accused of beating to death a pregnant woman who married against her family’s wishes.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Mohammad Iqbal said he was also beaten by the crowd of men. “When Farzana was killed, I fell on her body,” he said of his wife. “But they pulled me off and started beating her body and her face with their shoes.”

item.title: World Briefing: Detained Factory Workers in Cambodia Are Released
item.description: A Cambodian court on Friday convicted almost two dozen factory workers and human rights activists for instigating violence during protests early this year but then released them under suspended sentences.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: 2 Kidnapped Women Freed in Malaysia
item.description: A Chinese tourist and a Filipino worker have been rescued nearly two months after they were abducted from a resort off Borneo, Prime Minister Najib Razak of Malaysia said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: South Korean Sentenced in North Korea
item.description: North Korea sentenced a South Korean missionary to life with hard labor on Friday after convicting him of espionage and setting up an underground church.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing : Conviction in Terrorism Case in Canada
item.description: A jury on Friday convicted a former security guard from Toronto of attempting to join a foreign terrorist organization, a first for Canada.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing: Rebels and Tribesmen Clash in Yemen
item.description: Clashes between Shiite rebels and tribesmen backed by national army units in Yemen have killed at least 12 people, security officials and tribal leaders said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Argentine Official to Be Questioned Over Link to Firm That Prints Money
item.description: Vice President Amado Boudou must respond to accusations that he had abused his power to gain control of the company.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: Amado Boudou faces accusations of abuse of power.

item.title: Business Briefing: Value of British Economy to Include Illegal Drugs
item.description: Prostitution and the import, manufacture and consumption of illegal drugs like crack cocaine and heroin will be included in the official estimates of Britain’s economy, the national statistics agency said on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Walesa Among Ex-Leaders at Funeral of Political Enemy
item.description: Three of the country’s presidents attended services for Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, who declared martial law in 1981 amid labor unrest and a pro-democracy movement.
item.dc:creator: By RICK LYMAN
item.media:description: President Bronislaw Komorowski of Poland, right, and two predecessors, Aleksander Kwasniewski, standing, and Lech Walesa, at Mass on Friday.

item.title: Clinton Takes Responsibility for Benghazi
item.description: Hillary Rodham Clinton also pushed back against accusations that she tried to hinder a Republican-led investigation into the deadly assault.
item.dc:creator: By AMY CHOZICK
item.media:description: Hillary Rodham Clinton wrote in a book that “I was the one ultimately responsible for my people’s safety” in Benghazi, Libya.

item.title: Junta Sets Year’s Goals for Its Rule in Thailand
item.description: In a proclamation tightening control, the leader said that if “peace, order and reform” are achieved, democracy could return.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: A boy played while soldiers guarded a square to prevent protests in Bangkok on Friday. A military junta has banned demonstrations against its rule.

item.title: Open Source: Chilean Miners Recruited to Inspire World Cup Squad
item.description: The Chilean miners who spent more than two months trapped a half-mile underground in 2010 tell their country’s soccer team it has nothing to fear.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: New Refugee Camp in Jordan Tries to Create a Community for Syrians
item.description: Officials say the Azraq camp for Syrian refugees, in a remote, dusty expanse of Jordan, could grow even bigger than the Zaatari camp, which shelters more than 100,000 Syrians.
item.dc:creator: By RANA F. SWEIS
item.media:description: A Syrian family walked towards United Nations’ newest refugee camp, Al Azraq.

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Keep Talks Alive in Gas Feud
item.description: Negotiators reached a compromise that opens the door to further discussions, mediated by a top European Union official, over what Russia has called late payments.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE
item.media:description: Alexei Miller, the chief executive of Gazprom, on Friday in Berlin as gas negotiations mediated by the European Union’s energy commissioner continued between Russia and Ukraine.

item.title: Upshot With a Twist: A Summit Without Russia Needs a Drink to Match
item.description: The G7 forum in Brussels was originally to be held in Russia, so this cocktail replaces the Moscow Mule with one more suitable for Belgium.
item.dc:creator: By JOSH BARRO

item.title: Rio Grapples With Violence Against Police Officers as World Cup Nears
item.description: At least 110 officers have been shot in Rio so far this year, an increase of nearly 40 percent from the same period last year.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO and TAYLOR BARNES
item.media:credit: Ana Carolina Fernandes for The New York Times
item.media:description: Maria Rosalina Rafael Castilho showed a picture of her daughter, a police officer who was shot and killed in February.

item.title: European Agency Reports Surge in Illegal Migration, Fueling a Debate
item.description: The report by the agency feeds a debate on immigration that has led to political gains by far-right parties in the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL and DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: African migrants were rescued by the Italian Navy in the Mediterranean Sea this month in international waters between Italy and Libya.
